Day I left home for 
 the city 
 
 Lesley Koyi and Ursula Nafula 
 English 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
  
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 The smal bus stop in my vilage was 
 busy with people and overloaded buses. 
 
 On the ground were even more things to 
 load. 
 Touts were shouting the names where 
 
 their buses were going. 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 1  
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 “City! City! Going west!” I heard a tout
 shouting. 
 
 That was the bus I neded to catch.
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 2  
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 The city bus was almost ful, but more 
 people were stil pushing to get on. 
 Some packed their lugage under the 
 
 bus. Others put theirs on the racks 
 inside. 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 3  
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 New pasengers clutched their tickets as
 they loked for somewhere to sit in the
 crowded bus. 
 
 Women with young children made them
 comfortable for the long journey.
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 4  
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 I squezed in next to a window. 
 The person siting next to me was
 holding tightly to a gren plastic bag.
 
 He wore old sandals, a worn out coat,
 and he loked nervous. 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 5  
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 I loked outside the bus and realised that 
 
 I was leaving my vilage, the place where 
 I had grown up. 
 I was going to the big city. 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 6  
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 The loading was completed and al
 
 pasengers were seated. 
 Hawkers stil pushed their way into the
 bus to sel their gods to the pasengers.
 
 Each one was shouting the names of
 what was available for sale. The words
 
 sounded funy to me. 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 7  
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 A few pasengers bought drinks, others 
 
 bought smal snacks and began to chew. 
 Those who did not have any money, like 
 me, just watched. 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 8  
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 These activities were interupted by the
 
 hoting of the bus, a sign that we were
 ready to leave. 
 The tout yeled at the hawkers to get out.
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 9  
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 Hawkers pushed each other to make 
 their way out of the bus. Some gave back 
 change to the travelers. 
 
 Others made last minute atempts to sel 
 more items. 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 10  
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 As the bus left the bus stop, I stared out
 
 of the window. 
 I wondered if I would ever go back to my
 vilage again. 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 1  
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 As the journey progresed, the inside of 
 the bus got very hot. 
 
 I closed my eyes hoping to slep. 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 12  
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 But my mind drifted back home. 
 Wil my mother be safe? 
 Wil my rabits fetch any money?
 
 Wil my brother remember to water my
 tre sedlings? 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 13  
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 On the way, I memorised the name of the 
 place where my uncle lived in the big city. 
 
 I was stil mumbling it when I fel aslep. 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 14  
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 Nine hours later, I woke up with loud
 banging and caling for pasengers going
 back to my vilage. 
 
 I grabed my smal bag and jumped out
 of the bus. 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 15  
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 The return bus was filing up quickly. 
 Son it would make its way back east. 
 The most important thing for me now, 
 
 was to start loking for my uncle’s 
 house. 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 16
